messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: VLAD-VSA: Cross-Domain Face Presentation Attack Detection with Vocabulary Separation and Adaptation

Paper Abstract: Abstract. For face presentation attack detection (PAD), most of the spoofing cues are subtle, local image patterns (e.g., local image distortion, 3D mask edge and cut photo edges). The representations of existing PAD works with simple global pooling method, however, lose the local feature discriminability. In this paper, the VLAD aggregation method is adopted to quantize local features with visual vocabulary locally partitioning the feature space, and hence preserve the local discriminability. We further propose the vocabulary separation and adaptation method to modify VLAD for cross-domain PAD task. The proposed vocabulary separation method divides vocabulary into domain-shared and domain-specific visual words to cope with the diversity of live and attack faces under the cross-domain scenario. The proposed vocabulary adaptation method imitates the maximization step of the k-means algorithm in the end-to-end training, which guarantees the visual words be close to the center of assigned local features and thus brings robust similarity measurement. We give illustrations and extensive experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of VLAD with the proposed vocabulary separation and adaptation method on standard cross-domain PAD benchmarks. The codes are available at https://github.com/Liubinggunzu/VLAD-VSA.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Biometric liveness detection: Challenges and research opportunities",
        "NetVLAD: CNN architecture for weakly supervised place recognition",
        "All about VLAD",
        "Aggregating deep convolutional features for image retrieval",
        "Metareg: Towards domain generalization using meta-regularization",
        "Face spoofing detection using colour texture analysis",
        "Face Antispoofing Using Speeded-Up Robust Features and Fisher Vector Encoding",
        "OULU-NPU: A Mobile Face Presentation Attack Database with Real-World Variations",
        "Domain Separation Networks",
        "On the effectiveness of local binary patterns in face anti-spoofing",
        "Frustratingly easy domain adaptation",
        "Can face anti-spoofing countermeasures work in a real world scenario?",
        "Face liveness detection using dynamic texture",
        "Unsupervised domain adaptation by backpropagation",
        "Actionvlad: Learning spatio-temporal aggregation for action classification",
        "Deep residual learning for image recognition",
        "Aggregating local descriptors into a compact image representation",
        "Single-Side Domain Generalization for Face Anti-Spoofing",
        "Face de-spoofing: Anti-spoofing via noise modeling",
        "On the burstiness of visual elements",
        "Undoing the damage of dataset bias",
        "Deeper, Broader and Artier Domain Generalization",
        "Unsupervised domain adaptation for face anti-spoofing",
        "Domain Generalization With Adversarial Feature Learning",
        "3D Mask Face Anti-spoofing with Remote Photoplethysmography",
        "Learning deep models for face anti-spoofing: Binary or auxiliary supervision",
        "Deep tree learning for zero-shot face anti-spoofing",
        "On Disentangling Spoof Trace for Generic Face Anti-Spoofing",
        "Learning Transferable Features with Deep Adaptation Networks",
        "Face spoofing detection from single images using micro-texture analysis",
        "Unified deep supervised domain adaptation and generalization",
        "Domain Generalization via Invariant Feature Representation",
        "Your face is NOT your password",
        "Cross-database face antispoofing with robust feature representation",
        "Efficient domain generalization via common-specific low-rank decomposition",
        "Learning Meta Model for Zero-and Few-shot Face Anti-spoofing",
        "Image classification with the fisher vector: Theory and practice",
        "Generalizing Across Domains via Cross-Gradient Training",
        "Multi-Adversarial Discriminative Deep Domain Generalization for Face Presentation Attack Detection",
        "Joint Discriminative Learning of Deep Dynamic Textures for 3D Mask Face Anti-Spoofing",
        "Regularized Fine-grained Meta Face Anti-spoofing",
        "Video Google: A text retrieval approach to object matching in videos",
        "Visualizing deep similarity networks",
        "Face liveness detection from a single image with sparse low rank bilinear discriminative model",
        "To aggregate or not to aggregate: Selective match kernels for image search",
        "Generalizing to Unseen Domains via Adversarial Data Augmentation",
        "Cross-Domain Face Presentation Attack Detection via Multi-Domain Disentangled Representation Learning",
        "Unsupervised Adversarial Domain Adaptation for Cross-Domain Face Presentation Attack Detection",
        "Deep Spatial Gradient and Temporal Depth Learning for Face Anti-Spoofing",
        "Face Spoof Detection With Image Distortion Analysis",
        "Learn convolutional neural network for face anti-spoofing",
        "Searching Central Difference Convolutional Networks for Face Anti-Spoofing",
        "Face anti-spoofing via disentangled representation learning",
        "A dataset and benchmark for large-scale multi-modal face anti-spoofing",
        "A face antispoofing database with diverse attacks",
        "Ghostvlad for set-based face recognition",
        "Relja ArandjeloviÄ‡"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in VLAD-VSA: Cross-Domain Face Presentation Attack Detection with Vocabulary Separation and Adaptation, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
